Topic.Title: Ree: Dai Dynesty at Verisilicon & Marvell and Vivante from China robbed ON2 shareholders

Message.Msg: I posted this on VRNG board but first was blocked and then I had to post in differet chunks. Somone might be tRACING/TRACKING/mONITORING even while I might be typing? WOW??? The question one can ask is how many of those missing 25 of those semiconductor cpmpanies as ON2's "Over 50 semiconductor customers until today [December 2009]" were dealing with Dai's DYNASTY companies called Verisilicon, Marvell and Vivante, in addition to other companies like Ceva and more of Chinese unnamed companies??? And when did Tomi Jalonen, who's "Director of Product Marketing for Hantro video IP at VeriSilicon," was MOVED from ON2-Hantro to Verisilicon? Moving Tomi from ON2-Hantro was nOT any different from MOVING O'hare and Hieb from Hambrecht to Oppenheimer and then to another different company. Once in front of the Judge, ON2 Interim and BOD can argue that the rerason ON2 did not cite Hantro in the Dec-2009 document was because Google had trademarked the HANTRO logo, but again the question is how much did Google pay Interim, Bankoski, Luther, Reusing, Xu, Wilkins as Bonus or Google share options to keep them on Google side? Why ON2 did NOT inform or complain to SEC, FTC, ITC about Google trademarking its product called Hantro? Then, the main question the judge can ask is, who were those other 25+ Semiconducto companies as ON2 customers and what were Verisilicon, Marvell, Vivante, and Ceva's relation in all of these missing customers from ON2 list in the previous PRs? --Present: Tomi Jalonen, Senior Director, Hantro Video IP at VeriSilicon Holdings, Co. --Past: Tomi Jalonen, On2 Technologies, Inc. --In April 2, 2008 HANTRO was trademarked by Google? Let me give you real example, at least in my mind, that might be one way to simply a complex relationship among those seems to be involved to keep everything under control of a few involved to keep different links connected to two ends of the same line of rim of the same hub. --- Google was expecting to complete ON2 "merger" by December 2009, but ON2 shareholders voted it down three times and on Feb 16, as some ON2 shareholders complained on ONT-Yahoo-Messages-Board that they were blocked on Feb 15 to vote, 2010. --- FinnIM was a wrapper finish company as umbrella for Israeli companies that ON2 Interim-BOD decided to present ON2+Hantro+VP8 products under their shadows or "booth" in Barcelona, Spain, in Feb 2010, around the same day that ON2 "merger" voting also was set. --Always ON2 shareholders were told 25 semiconductor customers in the PRs. Where are the other 25 of 50 that Google and MF are talking about??? Why they NEVER told ON2 shareholders about the "other" 25?? --ON2's VP8 Video Decoder with VP8: It was called "G1" in December document, but now is called "Hantro G1" --ON2's Video Encoder with VP8: It was called "8290" in December document, but now is called "Hantro H1" casp321 ------- 2009/12 IMA-Finnmob_GSMA2010 IMA - FinnMob Pavilion at Mobile World Congress 2010 (Hall 4, Level 1) Package Payment Payment terms: Registration is final after first payment. 1. First payment, 7.000,00, by December 20, 2009. 2. Second payment, max. 7.000,00, by January 15, 2009. Cancellation terms: You will be charged 100% cancellation fee if canceling after December 20, 2009. $$$$$$$$??????? ------ It's Feb 4, 2010 I presume because of European format 2010/02 MWC10-IMA-FMA-Catalog-040210 Company references – Over 50 semiconductor customers until today, for example Nokia, Freescale, Mediatek and Infineon. Main partners - Investors – Publicly trade, AMEX:ONT Company References and Strategic Business Partners Configurable RTL designs, multiple video format and resolution configuration options for achieving the lowest possible silicon area utilization Only video IP in the world supporting the proprietary VP6, VP7 and VP8 video formats deployed for instance by Adobe and Skype Unique Differentiators G1 Multi-format Hardware Decoder: Support for H.264, MPEG-4, H.263, VP6, VP7, VP8, MPEG-2, MPEG-1, RealVideo, Divx and JPEG. Up to 1080p, 60fps decoding. 8290 1080p Encoder: H.264 Baseline/Main/High encoding up to 1080p, 60fps with built-in JPEG support up to 64Mpixel. Highly optimized software video codecs for ARM processor cores (ARM9, ARM11, Cortex A8, Cortex A9) Our Offering Power, silicon area and performance optimized configurable video codec IP designs for enabling multimedia up to 1080p encoding and decoding Proven track record in the semiconductor industry, over 50 semiconductor customers until today Easy integration and fast time to market, highly skilled technical support for IP integration and verification. Business Benefits & Customers Challenges On2 Technologies Finland is the industry leading provider of hardware and software based Hantro video codec IP products. Fully optimized to provide quality video at the lowest power requirements, On2´s TrueMotion VPx™ and standards based codecs (H.264, H.263, VC-1 and MPEG-4) implemented as SDKs and RTL (Hardware IP) for consumer semiconductor and device manufacturers, are deployed in more than 200 million handsets and proven in silicon through over 50 leading semiconductor companies. $$$$$$$$??????

Topic.Title: Ree: Dai Dynesty at Verisilicon & Marvell and Vivante from China robbed ON2 shareholders

Message.Msg: After, "merger" in Feb 2010: This's under on2 's official web site after they announced "G1" "Hantro G-Series 1" Video: Hantro G-Series 1 Video Decoder Multi-format configurable hardware design for multimedia integrated circuits (ICs) Decode WebM Video Content With Full Hardware Acceleration! The Hantro G-Series 1 multi-format RTL hardware decoder brings an unprecedented level of format and resolution support to enable all kinds of video applications. It is the first hardware decoder in the market to encompass full WebM video support, significantly extending the video playback time of Internet-connected and HTML5-enabled battery operated devices. Licensing Contact the following partners for licensing: •Verisilicon Holdings Co., Ltd. ---------- ---------- there are more but this is just one: 7/6/2006 VERISILICON COMPLETES SERIES-C FUNDING ROUND WITH AUSTIN VENTURES AND SIERRA VENTURES 7/6/2006 SANTA CLARA, Calif. and SHANGHAI, China, July 5, 2006 VeriSilicon Holdings Co., Ltd. (VeriSilicon), a leading world class ASIC design foundry that provides semiconductor IP, design and manufacturing services to customers worldwide today announced that it has raised US$ 14.8 million in its Series C financing co-led by Austin Ventures and Sierra Ventures. The Company will use the funding to finance the acquisition of the assets of the [ZSP] Digital Signal Processor business unit of LSI Logic Corporation ...; as part of this series-C funding, LSI Logic will also receive a certain number of VeriSilicon shares as part of the consideration for the recent acquisition of the assets of ZSP. In addition, the investment will support the Company's expansion of its operations, sales & marketing and engineering teams. --- Peter Wendell: Managing Director of Sierra Ventures Peter co-teaches Stanford University's Graduate School of Business, "Entrepreneurship and Venture Capital" with Google CEO, Eric Schmidt. Peter has held this faculty appointment at Stanford since 1991 and has now taught "Entrepreneurship and Venture Capital" to more than 1,000 Stanford MBAs because "it's a great way to stay connected to and help nurture the next wave of innovative companies." He has also been instrumental in applying his 25 years of U.S. VC experience to Sierra Ventures' entry into the new frontiers of India and China.

Message.Title: NY Times article: Electronics more important than cars to new generation. Guidance and apps get the attention.
Message.Msg: "there is a growing recognition that young people may simply not care about cars as much as their elders. Smartphones now rival automobiles as the default symbol of adulthood, and the portals to the world beyond home and school. Electronic technology competes ever more for the younger generation’s disposable income. As a result, in Paris automakers seem to spend more time talking about how well their cars interact with an iPhone than they do about engine performance. Connectivity is the new horsepower. “Before we talked about steering, ride and all those elements,” said Gunnar Herrmann, vice president for quality at Ford of Europe. “You could argue those are dropping down in importance. Connectivity is getting more important.” That means not only docks for smartphones but also technology like voice recognition to allow devices to be used while driving, or Internet radios that can stay tuned to the hometown station even when hundreds of miles away. Audi showed a concept car in Paris with onboard Wi-Fi so that passengers could remain connected while on the road. In essence, for the generation of mobile apps, carmakers are offering app-mobiles. “I think it’s true that the generation coming up now, who will be the car buyers for the next 20 years, are fairly unique,” said Douglas C. Speck, senior vice president for marketing and sales at Volvo. “They grew up in a world where computers and cellphones and connectivity all came together at the same time.” Few auto executives are ready to concede that young people will not want actual cars. “‘They like iPhones and iPods more than they like cars’ — you hear that,” said Ralf D. Speth, chief executive of Jaguar Land Rover, which is undergoing a renaissance due to investment from its new owner, Tata Motors of India. But, he said in an interview here, “everyone still needs to get from A to B.” There is a consensus, though, that younger buyers will want to get from A to B in a different kind of car. It must be more stylish. Performance is still important, but it must come wrapped in technology that appears more environmentally responsible. “They like technology. They like innovation. They like design,” said Luca Cordero di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, who noted that many of the company’s U.S. customers were young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. The shift in the market reflects not only competition from smartphones and other technology, but also the growth in the number of people around the globe who are living in urban areas. Cars are often unnecessary or even burdensome in places where there is good mass transit or networks of bicycle lanes of the kind that cities like New York and Paris have expanded in recent years. If a younger urban buyer wants any vehicle, it may be a fashionable small car like a BMW Mini or Daimler Smart that is easier to park, or even a radical new vehicle like the battery-powered Renault Twizy, which is beginning to appear on Paris streets. Half scooter, the narrow Twizy has four wheels, but the passenger seat is behind the driver. Younger buyers, raised in a social-networking environment, may also be more open to car sharing as an alternative to car ownership. Rental car companies and car-sharing services like the municipal Autolib’ in Paris or the commercial Zipcar in the United States may become even more important as fleet buyers. The digitally distracted consumer, meantime, may be happy to embrace cars that can drive themselves, freeing the driver to concentrate on Facebook, Twitter or whatever social media may be prevalent when self-driving technologies mature in a decade or so. (Google has already built working prototypes.) More immediately, manufacturers are trying to find ways to balance the craving for constant connectivity with the need for drivers to keep their eyes on the road. Voice recognition technology is already available in cars by Volvo and others as a way to operate some of the onboard electronics, and will become more sophisticated. BMW and others have heads-up displays that project information on the windshield in the driver’s line of sight. These technologies are likely to become less expensive and more common."
Good question. I bought the October 770 options in the hope that earning will be strong. If there is a big run up before earnings, I may bail.

Message.Title: Google must embrace and extend Apple Maps.
Message.Msg: The more I explore Apple Maps, the more I like it. This first 1.0 release already beats Google Maps even with it's flaws. 1. Vector based maps. 2. FlyOver 3. Turn-by-turn direction. 4. Point of interest Info, Reviews, Photos 5. Siri integration. If you honestly explore these things on the new iPad or the new iPhone the superiority is so obvious. I can wait for Bus, Train, Subway, Bike, Walking, Boat, underwater / Submarine routes to be integrated. No single company can provide all this information for the entire world many 3rd parties will do the job. Not to mention information like demographic, political, financial, crime etc that will be provided by third party. It a whole new gold rush folks. Apple has reinvented portable mapping... If Google is smart, they will embrace and extend Apple Maps by developing 3rd party layers for Apple Maps that will make use of Google Backend Data because the Apple architecture is much better. You will soon see a booming Apple Maps add-on layer market from 3rd parties all over the world. Does Google wants to stand by and let others take that market on Apple Maps when it already has valuable data? Time will tell.

Topic.Title: Google must embrace and extend Apple Maps.
